intro: Episcia hirtiflora, commonly known as the hairy-flowered waxplant, is a species native to tropical regions of South America. It is a member of the Gesneriaceae family, characterized by its fleshy, often hairy leaves and showy, tubular flowers. The plant typically grows as an epiphyte, attaching itself to trees in its natural habitat. Its flowers, which are usually bright red or orange, are adapted for pollination by hummingbirds. Episcia hirtiflora is popular in horticulture for its ornamental value and relatively easy care requirements.
